title: 111_hr2591
content: The Act may be cited as the "Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Act of 2009". It pertains to the modernization of the Integrated Public Alert and Warning System. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to modernize the integrated public alert and warning system of the United States for timely disaster warnings. The President, through the FEMA Administrator, is tasked with ensuring alerts reach governmental authorities and the public in disaster-prone areas. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to modernize the integrated public alert and warning system of the United States. The Administrator is required to establish common alerting protocols, adapt communications based on location and risks, and implement the public alert and warning system. The public alert and warning system in the United States is required to include capabilities for alerting individuals with disabilities and limited English proficiency, conduct training, tests, and exercises, incorporate multiple communication technologies, adapt to future technologies, and provide alerts to the largest portion of the affected population feasible. The public alert and warning system in the United States must alert individuals with disabilities and limited English proficiency, utilize various communication technologies, adapt to future technologies, and reach the largest portion of the affected population feasible. Pilot programs may be conducted to demonstrate different methods for meeting system requirements. The Administrator must submit a report to specific committees detailing the effectiveness of pilot programs, recommendations for additional authority, and any other findings and conclusions. The Administrator will submit a detailed plan for implementing the pilot programs, including a timeline, spending plan, and recommendations for additional authority to specific committees. Authorization of appropriations is also included. The Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Advisory Committee will receive $37,000,000 for fiscal year 2010 with additional funding as needed. The committee will be established by the Administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency within 60 days of the Act's enactment, with appointed members. The Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Advisory Committee will include the Chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the Assistant Secretary for Communications and Information of the Department of Commerce, representatives of State and local governments, emergency management agencies, emergency response providers, and representatives from federally recognized organizations. The Advisory Committee will also include individuals with technical expertise from various sectors such as communications service providers, vendors, developers, manufacturers, third-party service bureaus, the broadcasting industry, and noncommercial broadcast television stations. The Advisory Committee will include representatives from various sectors such as communications service providers, vendors, developers, manufacturers, broadcasting industry, noncommercial broadcast television stations, cellular industry, cable industry, satellite industry, national organizations for individuals with special needs, and other stakeholders as deemed appropriate by the Administrator. The Administrator or designee will serve as the Chairperson, and the initial meeting will occur within 60 days. The Advisory Committee will meet within 60 days of the Act's enactment. Subsequent meetings will be called by the Chairperson and must be noticed 14 days in advance and open to the public. One-third of members constitute a quorum. The Chairperson may establish subcommittees to assist in functions. The Advisory Committee, composed of subject matter experts, may adopt additional rules as necessary. They will develop recommendations for an integrated public alert and warning system, including protocols, standards, and operating procedures. The Advisory Committee, composed of subject matter experts, may adopt additional rules as necessary to develop recommendations for an integrated public alert and warning system. This system includes the distribution and content of communications based on geographic location, risks, or user preferences, alerting individuals with disabilities and limited English proficiency, incorporating multiple communication technologies, adapting to future technologies, and reaching the largest portion of the affected population. The Advisory Committee, composed of subject matter experts, may adopt additional rules to develop recommendations for an integrated public alert and warning system. This system aims to improve communication in remote areas, promote partnerships for community preparedness, and provide redundant alert mechanisms for widespread reach. A final report is due one year after the enactment of this Act. The Advisory Committee will submit a report with recommendations to the House of Representatives and the Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Advisory Committee, and it will terminate 60 days after submitting its final report. A technical correction is made to the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act. No statutory construction limitations apply to this section. The Department of Commerce and the Federal Communications Commission's authority will not be affected by this section, including the amendment.
